newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary's BUX ends down on Richter fall.
newsitem.headline: Hungary's BUX ends down on Richter fall.

text.p: An early surge in Hungarian shares on Friday was reversed by the losses of drug maker Richter on reports that Richter was to be sued by a U.S. business partner, traders said.
The BUX share index finished at 6,290.35 points, down 14.70 points or 0.23 percent, while spot share turnover soared to 5.3 billion forints from Thursday's 2.6 billion.

The index opened at 6,356.08 points and edged up to 6,367.95 points bolstered by a substantial rise in prices on the Wall Street, Thursday's announcement that the U.S. supported Hungary's early NATO membership and a strong dollar, traders said.
A rise in Hungarian share prices on London also contributed to the initial bullish mood, they added.
But a selling wave of Richter shares also pushed down other heavyweight shares like chemicals maker TVK, oil and gas company MOL and OTP Bank, from their intra-day highs, traders added.
"The reason was obviously Richter," said Attila Berecz of Raiffeisen Securities, adding that the major help for the Hungarian bourse was the Dow's overnight firming.
"Two major factors affected the bourse," said Credit Suisse First Boston analyst Spencer Jakab. "The first was the U.S. proposal of NATO membership for Hungary, and the other factors was Richter."

The U.S.'s Danco Laboratories Ltd. said on Thursday it had filed a suit against Richter for pulling out of its contract to manufacture a French abortion pill, and cited financial losses in excess of $200 million.
Richter ended at 15,300, down 550 forints on Friday as the news triggered a wave of selling the stock and traders said the story may weigh on the Budapest Stock Exchange in the next few days.
"This is a storm cloud over the market now," said Gyorgy Czipo of ING Barings. "We have to wait a few days until the story quietens down and is built into rices.
Traders added that the longer term outlook of prices on the BSE was positive.
